A bottle from Bishops. Colored a bit darker then normal Wit and more transparent. Rich fruity aroma. Traditional wit taste is mixed with bubblegum, very familiar cascade taste is quite recognizable.

.75 bottle. Yellow, slight golden, hazy. Wonderful bready aroma combined with some citrus, coriander. Palate is soft and full. Bready malts, some sourness, spices, esters. Wonderful, tasty, drink. One of the best ones ive had. Doesnt feel like a wit though, too heavy. Imperial wit?-- rated with beerbasher/harmattan

Refrigerated corked and caged 75 cl brown bottle poured into a weizen glass.  Pours beautiful light orange transitioning into a light golden with big fluffy white head.  A little lacing medium body, medium/light carbonation, and floral hop aroma.  Taste is citrus, floral hops, some coriander, and finishes bitter hops.  Wit Bock, or the marriage of a wit and an IPA, pretty good.
Cloudy pale golden body, white head. Hoppy and yeasty aroma with cereal, wheat, orange, grapefruit. Yeasty and dusty flavour with orange, lemon, wheat, with a bitter grapefruit finish.

Draft at The Birch.  Golden deep with a monster head.  Theres a definite twist of coriander on the nose.  Spicy finish, musty and reminiscent of a moldy old barn.  Nice full body.  Really nice floral end.  (#4628, 6/24/2012)

Bottle.  Vibrant cloudy golden beer with very strong white head.  The aroma is dry and yeasty, and the flavour is very bitter with a citric and malty thick finish. Overall a really good beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Rehills in Newcastle. Hazy golden coloured with strong lemon and vanilla notes with warming citrus fruits on the finish.

Fresh aroma of wet grass, lemon, subtle banana, orange and some citrusy hops. Taste is clean and has some yeasty notes, usual witbier flavours, banana, clove,  nicely balanced with  citrusy lemon and orange. Some sherbet like sweetness and spice. This is good!

Draft. Golden beer with a big cream head. Light spice and light wheat aroma with light noble hops. Light wheat and light malt flavor with noble hops and light grapefruit. Medium boldied. Light malt and light wheat linger with light spice and noble hops. Get more spice from hops than fruitiness.
Mid-amber with a fluffy white head. Lemon, corriander and pine on the nose. Fairly bitter, with sweet corriander and citrus hops. Soft with gentle carbonation.

Pours hazy pale amber with a large, fading head.
Nose shows piny and grassy hops as well as orange and lemon-like notes. Also some coriander. Quite light.
Flavours include the same orange peel and lemon alongside spicy hops, alcohol and grapefruit.
Nice high carbonation.
The hops and booze definitely dominate this one.

On tap at PJ Whelihans Dilworthtown.  Aroma of belgian yeast.  Has a cleary, kind of thick/syrupy appearance.  Minimal head and lacing.  Taste has citrus, hops, is highly carbonated, bit like a cross between a witbier and a tripel.  Taste and palate are complex - rich flavors, from banana to citrus to vanilla, and the palate lingers for a long time.  Very tasty

Pours a cloudy orange, nice head, the main flavour to this is the coriander which gives it the weissbeer flavour, however there are plenty of citrus hops to balance it and the end result is a very solid, easy to drink ale which, at 7.6%, should be a must try for fans of this style, goes down nice

Thanks to yespr for that one. Bottle looks good. Beer in the glass zippy, huge head. Fruity aroma. Starts fine fruity like lemon, modest sourish, not too much. Same salty hints. Finish well balanced, fruity with some yeasty notes. Quite drinkable. A good one!
cloudy amber with a very thick firm head. Yeasty and lemony aroma. Floral hops. Very barneyardy, musky and yeasty. Nice belgian

Pours a clear palle yellow with a medium foamy white head...great lacing.  Aroma has good spicy notes with mild citrus.  Flavor follows suit...good spicy wit!..nice bitterness...drinks a bit like a saison.  Mouthfeel is light/medium with a citrusy/hoppy bitter finish.  Very nice!
Very nice hoppy and complex wheat beer with a long and wonderful finish. Light amber hazy color.

75 cl bottle.
Rated on 20110625.
Pours slightly hazy orange color with a large, lasting head. Aroma of lots of fresh fruits, lemon, apricot and peach. Flavor of apricot and lemon. Mildly carbonated and hoppy bitter palate. Very crisp and refreshing when refrigerated properly.
4425
Aromàtica i contundent. Com a mi magraden. Molt bona cervesa de blat. Final llarg i lleugerament alcoholic. Genial.

Ottima Wit... o dovrei dire IPW come dice la descrizione?... Boh per me e un American Pale Wit... Aroma inebriante di luppoli americani con un tocco di citronella. Al palato attacco dolce, agrumata (pompelmo rosa, cedro e limone), caratterizzata da un amaro corrobante di fondo che rincara alla fine. Finale persistente. Assolutamente bilanciata fresca e beverina. Un ottima birra, qualunque sia il genere.
Yellow brown, cloudy. White foam, thick. Fruit aroma with a hing of banana, orange and apricot. Light fruit taste, alcohol, light bitter metallic aftertaste. Medium body high carbon
Bottle from total wine sac. Beer is orange in color with white head. Aroma is slight citrus. Beer has a banana flavor with that european yeast flavor. Good brew.
Overwhelming orange and citrus in aroma; medium carbonation.  Not so much taste though but nicely bitter and dry right there in the end.

13th August 2009Cloudy orange - gold beer. Dry semi soft palate. Citrus wheat flavours of orange and lemon just about hold their own against a fair bit of hop. It all adds up to a sharp fruity beer with a bitter finish. Goes down very easy.

Bottle at Green Lion Inn, Malmö, April 2012.

Hazy pale golden with a large, creamy head. Fresh and crispy with hops, bread and some perfume. Really drinkable. Would love to drink this in the coming summer.
750ml bottle from Alko. Hazy yellow colour with huge head. Aroma is wheat. Flavour is wheat with nice hop kick.

330ml bottle. Translucent, semi-misted (initially) straw with a shallow, clumping white head. Aroma (initially) reminiscent of Oakham JHB; floral, zesty with lemon and lime hop and perfumed coriander, developing more tropical, lychee notes. Warming, peppery citrus and orange rind on the palate, with more tropicality (mango, lychee, passion fruit) and bitterness than any witbier could lay claim to. Refreshing, but you can sense the underlying heat.  A lingering, perfumed waft of coriander and oatmeal smoothness nodding towards Tripel Karmeliet. A totally natural and successful fusion of styles.

Helt vanlig ordinär belgisk öl. Inget spännande. Små belgiska toner men Intet mer 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged. Cloudy amber with a short fizzy white head. Aroma is strong spices, dried flowers, dusty yeast notes, tropical fruit, perfumey soap, and herbs. Taste is just as spicy with more big yeast notes, wheat sweet malt, citrus zest, flowers, and herbal notes. Body is light-medium with a strong, effervescent carbonation. Finishes with big dusty yeast notes, herbs and spices, dried flowers, zesty citrus, tropical fruit and wheat notes.

Odd aroma of makeup and roses, accents of coriander and oranges. The aroma could pass for an older womans perfume. Opaque amber, thin head. Unripe orange flavor, lemon zest. Tangerines are discernible when quaffed. Subtle notes of lemongrass and grapefruit peel are also present. Violet seems rather prominent. Bitter and floral for the style.  Rose petal finish. Filmy mouthfeel. This certainly isnt just another wit. Strongly hopped, but not with hops one would expect to be paired with the typically fruity notes of a wit. Outrageously complex, but it seems like too much, especially for a wit. With so much going on, its easy to find something to like, but equally as easy to find something to dislike. Lacks direction and cohesion. This is probably an example of a White IPA that seems to be the new fad, but this beer exposes a vulnerability in marrying an IPA and a wit. That is, the style itself is already complex and needs no complicated hopping regime to muddy the waters.  It should probably only be single hopped.
Bottled. Mikkeller Not Just Another Wit lived up to its name as it was like regular witbier with extra boost from hops and a bit fuller malty body aswell. A great wit!

750 mL bottle. Pours hazy gold with a small, bubbly, white head and lots of lacing. The aroma is citrus forward, with notes of limes and lemon peels, wheat, and a pilsener-ish note that is probably from the saaz hops. The flavor is malty and sweet, and surprisingly bitter for a witbier. The finish is mild and a little sour. The palate is light, effervescent, and sticky. Overall, this is a strangely powerful witbier, with a strong aroma and flavor, and forward hop profile. Very interesting, and very tasty.

750mL bottle, pours a cloudy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, coriander, hay, citrus, orange peel and yeast - quite doughy. Flavour is quite white wine like, with dough, spicy orange peel, wheat and coriander. Tons of depth for a witbier - quite unorthodox for the style, since it transcends the usual weak flavour profile.

(Draught) Pours hazy yellow to pale golden. The aroma is medium to heavily hoppy and light doughy with notes of bread and resin. The flavour is doughy and floral/perfumey/fruity/resinous bitter with a dry finish. The mouthfeel is clean. Light alcohol notes. Medium bodied.

Bomber from the Perfect Pour, Elkridge. Nice to snatch up a few Mikkellers that dont make it down to NC. I was unbowed in grabbing this one despite my general "eh" feeling about wits. Pours a cloudy deep gold with a serious murk at its center and a crisp thin film of bubbles. Happily, the nose is terrifically funky. Taste gives you a good dose of hops, a bit of fruit, and a dankness that makes this clearly a farmhouse style wit, quite good.

Bottle given to me by a friend, I believe she picked up at a Whole Foods in Dallas Texas. Pours a cloudy yellow colour, with a bright white head and dripping layers of lacing. Aroma is so very fresh, Belgian yeast, sweet, and some banana and orange. Tastes bitter, light malt after taste. fresh fruitiness and spice. Really refreshing. Another gem.

Cloudy orange, big spongy white head. Smells like Tang, coriander and grassy hops. Smooth and tasty - grassy hops, some pine, too, plus some traditional wit flavors, too. It seems that Hoppy wits or white IPAs or whatever are becoming a thing now, this is the first one Ive really enjoyed.
Bottle from Superbest Rødovre. Yellow colour with a white head, Aroma and flavour of yesat, fruit, malt and hops.

Clear gold with a soapy, lacing, white head. Aroma of citrus, flowers, kiwi, spice, and toffee. Taste is mild bitterness and sweet malt and fruit, with a bit of yeast character. Light-medium bodied with mild carbonation. An interesting take on a wit, not my favorite, but good, and unique.

Questa Mikkellere mantiene quello che promette. Non è la solita birra bianca, anche se il colore è esattamente quello. Già al naso si notano le differenze. Tutto è più intenso e in bocca è molto equilibrata con note agrumate nette e una buona luppolatura. Ottima.

Im generally dont like witbier all that much.. This being not just another wit i decided to go for it. I really liked this one. Never had a witbier  this hoppy. The witbier notes actually made a really good balance to the hops, its like a mix between an ipa and witbier - me like.

Bottle from Ölkonsortiet cons 2011-12-05 Göteborg
AR: a bit yeasty, elder flowers, some honey
AP: hazy amber colored body, 2 m thick fizzy/stouthy bone white head
F: warming fealing, tropical fruits, citric, caramel, dry, honey, medium + bitterness/ carbonation, finsih is rater bitter and fruity

Tap. Light orange-brown with an attractive, eggshell white head. The aromas of toasted pine nuts, wood, lively yeast,  grass, citrus. A really complex nose. Bitter, hop-forward flavor thats buoyed by some of the natural sweetness from the cascade hops. Full-bodies. Overall, another well-constructed Mikkeller offering.

Draught @ The Rover on December 3. Pours hazy orange yellow with a creamy white head that leaves lots of trace while dissipating. Smell is malty sweet, lemon zest, fudge, orange zest, butter and pine. Taste is slightly sweet and slightly bitter with banana, bubblegum, cloves and lemon zest. Finish is dry an slightly bitter.

on tap. pours clear golden  light orange, Aroma: light coriander, banana, yeast, cloves, grassy hops, fruity, belgian sweetness, peach, tangerine, citrussy hops, Taste: wheat, light cloves, coriander, orange peel, grassy and citrussy hops, yeast, some bitterness, fresh, floral, lemon, some malty sweetness. not that into wit, but this does it for me.

Long Island, NY - A really good beer. Yellow and light golden in color. Coriander very strong in it. Lots of citrus flavors. A really good beer. I like the mix between the hoppyness and the witbier notes.

On tap. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is banana, orange, peach, hops, bready yeast, some popcorn and citrus. Taste has lots of crispy refreshing hops, citrus, wheat, peach, bread, corn and very light banana is here aswell.
nice soft aroma,yellow,hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, soft carbonation, nice soft hoppy aroma,

Pours a hazy orange color with a mediumsized white head. Arom of clove, ornage peels and citrus. Flavour is lightly acidic with notes of citrus, orange peel and clove. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. A nice wit.

[10/5/11] Bottle at Cafe Viking in Copenhagen. Clear golden with a white head. Fruity hoppy aroma with citrus, flowers and piney hints. Bitter hoppy flavor with lots of grapefruit. Medium-bodied. Nice.
Way more spices than any regular Belgian wit and not that wheaty. Really pretty good stuff. Thanks Anthony!

Great. In a Belgian wit style but with more hops. Its so smooth. Lovely mandarin fruit. Hazy pale gold, lasting white head. Creamy in mouth. Thats just stunning. Great great cleaning hops on the finish on one of my favourite styles.

0.75 l bottle, thanks hanniku! Hazy copper orange color. Perfumed aroma with clove, pepper, oily tangerine, herbal orange pith and dust. Sweetish bitter and orangey flavor with clove, pepper, vanilla, citrus and orange. Full bodied.  Quite tasty but there is some controversy between bitterness and spiciness. Not drinkable.

33 cl Bottle at Mogwai, Helsingborg. June 2011.

Pours hazy golden with a thick white foam. Creamy wheat aromas with notes of grassy hops, lemons and oranges. Some light spice as well. Thick and rich body, very flavourful. It does have a high bitterness for being a wit thanks to the hops which also shines through in the taste. Still it feels balanced and smooth. An interesting wit for sure!

Huge white head over hazy yellow beer with an orange taint. Faintly spicy nose, wheat and a fruity addition hinting at USA hops. Despite some wheat, rather mild-bitter, superbly fruity hops dominating. Medium bodied, quite slick, as if fruity filling in. Long-lasting hopflavours. Not just another wit?? This is more the Wit all other wits ought to be...

Smell of coriander. Huge creamy head. Amber colour. Strong aroma of nuts and coriander, also alcohol and citrus to be found. Also, hops. Medium sweet and lightly bitter, also medium sour. In general Id say its a very courageous attempt to brew a beer. And quite successful, also.
Bottle at the Green Lion in, Malmö. Classicwit nose and taste, but, with an extra hop dimension and grassy bitterness. Strong, fresh, dryish and very well balanced between strength and drinkability.

Bottle, 33 cl: Cloudy golden beer with a white head. Interesting fruity, bready aroma: Notes of hay, dough and wheat combined with orange, lemon-cest and a spicy touch of coriander.
Its heavy sweet and medium bitter with a little tartness underneath. Medium body, oily texture, average carbonation and a somehat short bittersweet finish. Refreshing hoppy take on a Wit.
Cerveza de trigo bien lupulada.color amarillento palido.mucho sabor de cilantro.refrescante.

Frothy and lacy head. Slightly darker orange than your average wit, hazy of course. Hoppy and spicy nose: sweet exotic fruits, citrus, resins + lots of coriander and orange peel. Spicy yeast has ripe fruits, strawberry, cloves and some pepper. Fres wheat maltiness, surprisingly dry cosidering the strength. Bitter finish with sour and spicy yeast and lingering coriander flavor. Medium bodied, smooth and rich texture. Finishes slightly sticky/yeasty and bitter.

Bottle. Slightly hazy golden pour, huge white head. Aroma is floral hops, citrus, pepper, spices and coriander. Flavor is spicy bitter hops, slightly fruity, citrus peel. Lively carbonation. Nice brew, but not really a normal witbier.

0.33l bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen shared with ClubGonzo and the rest of Bergen Tasting Crew. This is a cloudy yellowish beer with a nice bubbly and lasting white head. Aroma is really nice; really hopy - almost unnatural hopy, light sweet, some yeast and wheat, light citrus hints and notes of wet leafs. Soft carbonation, oily texture and medium-bodied. Tastes light wheat, some flowers, mild hopy - less then the aroma would suggest, some hints of alcohol in the finish and a lasting mild malty and light yeasty aftertaste. Not your typical wit indeed. Someone said DWIT? A new genre?
Pours hazy yellow with fluffy white head. Peppery hoppy aroma. Taste is sicy but light, long bitter finish

Had this was Dad for his B-day at Pine Lake Trout Club. truly my favorite Wit ever. poured cloudy, golden, huge white pillowy head. Spearmint, clove, orange peel, grass, vanilla on nose. really complex flavors. vanilla, citrus hops, soft and creamy palate. I dont know what it is but this is outstanding.

33 cL bottle at the Great British Beer Festival 2011.  Looks like a belgian wit, orange/yellow and cloudy, lots of head.  Hints of citrus, bit like Hoegaarden but better.  Nice light citrus aroma.  Dry aftertaste, very nice.  Doesnt taste like its 7.6%

A very refreshing Wit, it sort of reminds me of Vesterbro Wit, but on steroids. Quite hoppy and on the nose you get alot of orange zest and also some apricot. Taste the banana and grapefruit shows upp and some alkohol. Its very refreshing, but the alkohol taste wasnt that pleasant.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2011 Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, shared with Palme and friends. Pours a light orange hazy body with a medium white head. Nose is grassy wheaty cat piss tones, hints of perfumy spices. Some citrus. A bit hard to define. Taste is floral wheaty tones with hints of perfume again. A bit of alcohol presence and a grassy, bitter finish. A Wit? This one? Im thinking maybe some cross between a Saison and an APA, and I think its a bit unfair to the brewers of "real" wit to have this rather unclassifiable (yet nice) beer topping the wit charts. Still, a rather nice beer from Mikkeller.

Thanks to TorbenH for this one. Golden coloured and hazy. Heavy hoppy aroma, faint notes of red berries too. Flavor is moderate sweet and heavy bitter. Way too expensive! Dry texture. Lively carbonation.

Big offwhite head. Hazy deep yellow body. Herbal mealy coriander aroma, sort of subdued. Dry-sweet intense coriander taste with wheaty notes. MId-bodied. Sharp mouthfeel. Dry citric wheaty coriander aftertaste with syrupy herbal notes. Big, bold flavour, but perhaps a bit sharp and not harmonic enough. (0.33l bottle, Salling, Århus.)

Location/Date:Draft at Jack Rose on 7/23.
Appearance: Pours a nice clear gold. 
Aroma: Mostly a lot of wheat.
Taste: A decent amount of bitterness for the style.
Palate:Light to medium body.
Summary: This was a nice "wit-IPA"

Thought this was freakin delicious.  Id best describe it as a dry-hopped wit.  Cloudy and very grassy without being sweet, with a big sharp hop kick.  Relatively thick, extremely refreshing.  On tap at Jack Rose in adams Morgan, NW DC.
Hazy yellow colour. Smells great! Lovely hops, some citrus.. Wow. Tastes as one would expect from the smell. Love it. Pretty heavy on the carbo, but it suits the beer.

Slightly hazy light yellow color, almost no head. Very hoppy smell; incredible. Taste is very nice but dominated by too high carbonation. Taste fruits and hop. Carbo as said (too) high with a medium body. But indeed not just another wit!
Bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Originally rated on 17.9.2010. Excellent, strong and spicy witbier.
Hazy yellow, white head. Intense aroma of spices, wheat and mandarine. Flavour adds little yeasty taste with greapefruits. Floury palate.

75 cl, bottled. Pours cloudy amber with a frothy white head. Aroma: Fruits, citrus, yeast, hints of spruces and vanilla, wood. Taste: Light sweetness, high bitterness. Palate: Soft, creamy. Medium (+) body, average carbonation. Bitter. Nice.

Bottle. Poured a slightly hazy yellow-light orange color. The head was two fingers high and white with good retention and lacing. Baking spices, lemon-lime soda, flower blossom, and perfume in the nose. Light to medium bodied and delicately sweet. Flaky pastry, spices, citrusy hop (lemon, lime, orange), and fairly strong alcohol flavors.

75cl bottle from Alko. Poured hazy orange color with a creamy looking, lasting white head. Strong aroma of citrus and wheat in aroma. Flavor is citrus, yeast, hops and slight sweetness towards finish. Very refreshing and slightly different witbier. Excellent!

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange color. The head is frothy white.
Hoppy aroma, sweet and citrusy. It is a little bready.
Very hoppy flavour and citrus fruits. The breadiness is there but not too forward.
Smooth mouthfeel and a dry aftertaste.
Amazing beer which I will for sure pick up again.

Aroma: fruity and estery; lots of orange, nice Belgian yeast aromas, light grains, fruity hops.  Golden-orange color with white head, decent retention.  Flavor is oranges, tropical fruit, spicy hops and Belgian yeast, grapefruit and mango.  Noticeable alcohol presence, but this is fairly well hidden.  Slightly higher bitterness than is common for the style, but it works well since its a bigger beer.  Medium-full body, medium carbonation, smooth and creamy on the palate.  A bit bigger beer than Im used to for a wit, but it all comes together really well.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2012 75 cl bottle
Lots of hops and exotic fruits in the aroma. Flavor has fresh hops and some fruits too. Wit is rather hard to observe beyond all the hops.

750 ml bottle. Hazy golden yellow colour, thick and creamy white head. Aroma of orange, wheat, lemon, hops and spices. The flavour is sweetish, wheaty-malty, with citrus fruits and a spicy, aromatic hoppy finish. A delicious hybrid of a wit and an IPA.
Pours cloudy golden with a high head. Aroma is bitter malts and spices. Flavor is quite bitter too. Wheat, malts, spices and hops. Not a witbier really, but great.
750 bottle-thanks to jtclockwork for sharingpours a big off white shaving cream head and hazy yellow/gold color.  Aroma is lemon, light malt/wheat.  Taste is lemon hops, spice, light malt/wheat.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2012 A slightly orange colour, a head is big and beige. Aroma is fresh and tastefull, lots of oranges, witbier like fruityness and spicyness, coriander and tropical fruity hoppyness. Taste is like aroma, oranges, spicys and grapefruity hoppyness, hint of black peppers; interesting witbier with nicely long and medium bitter and aromatic aftertaste. Medium bodied, nice carbonation, but not so refreshning as usual because of quite high alc.%, but so what when the taste is great. Very interesting beer, where the stronger hoppyness gives something new into this style, I like this beer.
Had this at a summer cabin from a pint. Citrus, aromatic hops and wheat. Rather bitter. Excellent witbier.

Bottle 75 cl. Poured hazy orange in colour with thick and creamy white head. Citrus, yeast and wheat in aroma. Some spices, hops and sweetness is also present. Flavour is grassy bitter and spicy with some sweet lemon and ashes in taste at first. Hops and sweetness dominates the flavour. Feels and tastes in the end more like a double IPA than a witbier. Quite pleasant grassy bitter and sweet aftertaste. Definately a good beer in the summertime. Very smooth and highly enjoyable.

Sourish aroma, picking up some "amarillo" and bitter orange zest.
Taste of bananas, orange, belgic yeasts. Sweet.

Bottle. Pours a nice cloudy orange color with a frothy white head. Aroma is really nice filled with hops, sweeter citrus fruits like orange and tangerine, some breadiness, spice and wheat. The flavor is also quite hoppy with citrus notes, again the sweeter citrus fruits especially orange, some wheat, spice in the way of clove, coriander and orange peel, breadiness and wheat. The body is medium with a very smooth mouthfeel. Overall a fantastic Witbier, probably all time favorite in the style.

Draft taster at Bavarian Lodge. This is cloudy yellow like a Belgian white. I could not pick up much of a nose here. But when I tasted it, I got the most viscous sip of beer ever to cross my tongue. Or was it the thick malts with lots of fizz giving me that impression? Its a hoppy wrapper around a creamy center of Belgian light malt. Hops are an unusual combo, with rough Amerillos and Cascade laced up with English Goldings and Czech Saaz. Theres also the usual lemon peel of the style.

On tap at the house of 1000 beers. Now I know why this beast rates so high, this site is full of hop lovers and this is a hoppy white beer. Big giant over the top foaming pour from the tap. Clean almost lemon yellow appearance. Surprizingly floral hop aroma. Quite rude from the top, certainly not a wit beer as we know them. Bitter and hoppy. Over the top, what else could I expect from this brewer. At least call this a wheat ale for cryen out loed, has all the rude ale attributes of a mild IPA. Flat. Quite dissapointing, way too much money for this wit beer wanna bee.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours hazy yellow-gold decent sized sticky white head. Leaves some nice lacing throughout. Aromas are mild - some floral hops, a little yeast, coriander. Flavor is actually surprisingly intense. Bittersweet, citrusy hops with orange zest, spicy peppercorn and wheat. Nice, crisp carbonation - refreshing.
Unclear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, yeasty, spicy and moderate hoppy - citrus. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and bitter finish. 290509

On tap; pour is light gold with an average white head in this glass; sticky cobweb lacing presents itself nicely. An ipw indeed! Strong floral hop aromas, orange peel, and spices. The initial bitterness on the tongue is the game changer for me; very hop forward,  with a more expected orange zest and coriander element, with light malts rounding it out. The bitterness lingers on the tongue, while the tangy funk is present but not as noticeable because or the hop presence. Excellent unique brew, at least by my standards.
Incredible wheat beer.  Clean aroma, super smooth.  Ultra cloudy experience.  Definitely not just an ordinary wheat beer!
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 Bottle. Haze yolk yellow. Small head. Nice mild flowers blended with faint citrus (orange). Slight sour with a smooth very bitter finish. Strong wit.
Bottle shared with jcwattsrugger. Pours cloudy orange. Off white head. Nose/taste of lemon, banana and wheat. Mouth feel is full - some spiciness to taste that was not present in the nose.

750 from Capones.  Pours hazy canary with huge fluffy white head.  Nose is spicy florals, limey citrus, coriander, orange zest, saazy hops.  Great nose on this.  Tastes spicy, with the coriander and orange zest up front, Saaz hops, yeasty spicy florals, and a crisp, smooth, complex palate.  This is a world class wit.

This poured a cloudy very cloudy light yellow color with a white head. Aroma was of light/medium spices, as well as herbal and citrusy hops. Flavor was very hopped for a wit, but didnt take away from the nice spicey and fruity notes of the wit. Overall a very nice example of the style.

33cl bottle. Pours light yellow, a bit cloudy, with a big white head. Soapy foam and long retention (hop extract maybe?). Aroma is decisely hop-forward, with big piney notes. Some grass and floral notes too. Taste is again hoppy with a nice wheat presence. Some peppery spiciness too. Good body and lively carbonation. Definitely a different, pumped-up, wit. But not what I look for in this style. Still very well brewed and refreshing.
Sample @ Beerexpo, Lkpg. Hazy golden and big white head. Aroma brings banana, coriander, hops, pepper and citrus in a fantastic blend! Flavor is quite simular to the aroma. Fantastic.

Hazy yellow with a thick dense white head. Has the aroma of an ipa with grape fruit and grass added orange peel. Flavor is more witlike, with the fruity yeast comming through along with coriander and orange peel. Again added a pretty high bitterness uncommin for wit beers. Nice and fresh.

It got an unclear golden colour.
Aroma is alittle yeasty, with  alot of orange, hops (cascade?)
Flavour is more hops, ALOT of citrus. Alittle soapy in the aftertaste, but a good body. Medium lenght and highly hopped to be a wit. But it´s not just another wit so...
Summary; A different, and "imperial" wit? Likey

33cl bottle; my brewery tap, many thanks

Poured into La Chouffe glass.Huge orange haze and white lacing which diminishes rapidly. 

Aroma is orange peel; lemon zest, coriander, very hoppy, can definitely feel the Amarillo hops coming through and I love those hops, there is also pine, marzepan and candy sugar on aroma too. 

Taste is lemon zest, orange peel, tart, coriander, sorbet, marzepan, bubblegum, toffee, lovey citrus hiop bite, really nice hop bite actually, full in the mouth and big bold and fruity tropical finish. Wow really impressed with this one. Thanks Mikkeller for another great non-questionable pick up beer!

Tap at Haandverkerstuene. Very hazy golden color, large white head. Aroma of orange, mild hops, banana, spices. Taste of banana, wheat and light malt, also some spices here. Good bitter finish, that stays for a long time. It does have a bit alcohol taste, though Ive never had a wit this strong before, so its probably no wonder. Another good beer by Mikkel!

24/03/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (tap). Dorata, lievemente più scura delle normali blanche, quasi limpida, con schiuma bianca fine e cremosa. Aroma intenso e pungente di luppolo, da cui emerge una nota acidula di frumento. In bocca si presenta subito amara, aggressiva, frutto di una luppolata generosissima, un po invadente ma che ha il merito di bilanciare le note acidule del frumento con un risultato assolutamente inedito e curioso. Non molto strutturata, a dispetto della gradazione alcolica importante.
Bottle. Slightly hazy golden with small off-white head. Flavour is malt, hops, wheat, bitter, spices, citrus, coriander and a little sweet.

Pour cloudy golden with white head good lacing. Aroma orange peel, pepper, kitchen spices, cloves, banana, bubble gum, and big floral hops. Taste WOW big hops grassy and floral, pepper, spices, cloves, orange rind, coriander, slight wheat. MF medium body decent carb. Overall wow great hoppy beer well done.

Bevuta alla spina alla Brasserie 4:20 (Rome) - Non la solita wit. Dorata con riflessi ambrati, limpida, con schiuma fine e abbastanza persistente. Al naso colpisce la luppolatura generosa, ma anche le note di frumento che emergono bene sullo sfondo. In bocca è unesplosione di luppolo, che bilancia alla perfezione le note acidule tipiche delle blanche, a tutto vantaggio delleleganza. Unica pecca, con una gradazione alcolica di questo tipo avrei gradito un filo di corpo in più. Comunque una eccellente birra. Per me che non amo il genere, una vera scoperta!
Hands down the best wit I have had to date. Smells of coriander, banana, and other spices. The beer taste beautiful.

On tap at Cask Pub and Kitchen, Pimlico, London last November. A hazy golden coloured pour with a decent white head. Belgian yeasty, banana aroma. Tastes similar, banana, yeasty, wheaty, sweet, fruity, malty. More like a turbo charged Belgian whaet beer but very enjoyable all the same.

11-MAR-2011, tap @Mikkeller Bar.
Golden with white head..
Lovely complex weissbier.
It truly is not just another wit. It has all the "ordinary" wit-elements. It is smooth and yeasty. But then the hops kick in adding new layers. Also a tiny bretty note?

draft @ Delirium, Brussels.
dorée brumeuse, mousse blanche.
Arôme levure, houblon avec note de citronnelle, orangée avec qcq épices coriandre avec une impression de vanille?
En bouche, je note ce profile de blanche mais avec cet aspect houblonné donnant une touche daiguille de sapin. Douce au palais avec rappelant la camomille, fruitée avec citron/orange/ananas 
Une blanche agréable avec un profile qui aurait pour base une IPA ou vice versa.

750ml bottle.
Hazy golden pour with some white head - fruity, citrus and floral hop aromas.  Usual witbier bite with some slight bitterness - I wouldve never guessed this was nearly 8%.  Very interesting and different.
Tasted 2011-03-09. Pours hazy, yellow with white head. Hoppy, yeasty, bretty, wheaty - goody.

Tap at Patricks, Kristiansand. Pours hazy dark orange with white head. Aroma is banana, citrus, yeast. Taste is light sweet, light bitter, light sour. Light to medium body, thin, soft to average carbonation. 23022011

Tap@Håndverkerstuene. Hazyu golden with a big offwhite creamy head, loads of lace. Looks delicious. Aroma is very fruity, apricots, lemons, banana, some spicy notes, some of that wheat sourness. The spicy notes come through a bit more in the flavour, loads of fruity sweetness here, and that heavy, thick wheat ale body that I love. This was an awesome drink to be honest. Refreshing and sweet all in one. Just too bad it clocks in at 7,6%, otherwise itd be an awesome sessioner.

Draught @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours hazy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of wheat, yeast and hops. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Draught at Håndverkerstuene. Low, off-white, lacing-head atop of cloudy, amber body. Sappy aroma of fruits. Potpourri of fresh citrus fruits in flavour added by lighter hints of spices. Dry bittersweet finish. Ultrafresh (Oslo, 07.02.2011).

From tap@Håndtverkerstuene, Oslo. Tall foamy white head. Murky, dark orangey-yellow body. Superfresh lemony hop aroma. Notes of of flowers and perfume. Fresh-tasting citrus is dominating the flavor as well, mostly lemon and citrus peel. Yeast notes and some faint spice, coriander maybe. Crisp pale malte in the backbone. No disturbing alcohol, a discreet sweetness only. Mid-bodied. Nice citrus-hoppy ending. Very likeable.

Pours nice and cloudy, light gold in color. Aroma is orange rind, pepper and coriander. Wow. Bitter. Typical coriander spice flavors but finishes up with a strong citrusy hop flavor. Maybe some pine in there, too. Lingering bitterness. Nice carbonation. Very interesting take on the style, definitely worth trying.

And jester that Amund at Håndverkerstuene is I got three glasses as well. Hazy orange colour with a small head. The other two glasses was filled to the brim with a mountain of a very creamy head. Aroma is yeasty with some sweet and sour and overtones. Flavour is bitter and yeasty. Some dough as well as some spice, coriander perhaps, faint hints of orange peel. Flavour is vaguely bitter. Heavy notes of yeast as well as dough, coriander and pepper. Short aftertaste.

Bottle @ home. Hazy golden orange appearance with a small white head. Yeast, citrus, and pine in the light wheat nose thats slightly spicy. Flavor has a bit of a piney hoppiness with a yeasty light wheat flavor. Some citrus in their too. Doesnt taste like 8% ABV. Finish is a little hoppy with light wheat malts. Unique.

(Draught at Cask Pub & Kitchen, Pimlico, London, 27 Nov 2010) Hazy golden colour with frothy, white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with notes of citrus, coriander, fresh floral hops and sourish wheat hints. Fruity, hoppy taste with grass, citrus, a slightly sourish wheat character and generous amounts of fresh, floral, citrussy hops. Medium body, with balanced sweetness and - for the style - an impressive bitterness. As stated ... not just another wit. Very nice and quite refreshing.

750 ml bottle from Wine and Cheese Place.  Pours a cloudy, dull gold color with a large, foamy eggshell white head.  Aroma of wheat, gentle citrus, clove, apricot, coriander, yeast, and candi sugar.  Flavor of orange citrus, wheat, sweet malts, floral notes, coriander, herbal notes, and yeast.  Medium-bodied, with soft carbonation and a wheaty, malty mouthfeel.  Nice beer and a good way to start off a session where we opened a lot of barley wines.

On tap at the Cask, Pub and Kitchen enjoyed whilst pondering over the crossword during the very fine Mikkeller Day on 27/11/10. Cloudy gold pour with a fluffy white head. Fresh herbs, wheat and ginger in the nose. Crisp citrus kick with a splash of ginger. Spicy, flavoursome mouthfeel. More spices ease their way gently through in the finish.

On tap at the CASK Pub & Kitchen, London on 27th November 2010. Hazy gold; white lacing head. Cheesy and yeasty aromas and a little cinnamon spice and some fruits. Citric burst in-mouth, rich spiciness and lemon-grapefruit zing. A fairly short, sharp, but briefly exquisite grassy aftertaste on a zingy texture. Beautifully crafted.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2010 A Sim rate (on tap at the Cask): Sweet yeasty wheat. Flavour thats tartly wheaty. Like a ...dare I say it?... wit. Finish thats malt and wheat. Bitterness thats a real kick. The lacing is an impressive binding sort reminiscent of a great Brugge lace.
Nose of wit, soap, feel is mediumbroad, carb is balanced, taste follows nose
Overall a great wit.  Very light yet still flavorful.  Given the choice of wit styles I would save my money and grab some Hoegarden but head to head this Mikkeller would win out in taste.

750 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu. BBE 23/10/11.
Pours a deep copper colour with a big foamy white head. Fruity on the nose with wheat, dark fruits, citrus and yeast. Hoppy taste with classic Witbier-elements; wheat, fruits citrus and barnyard. Medium bodied, lively carbonation and a sticky/oily mouthfeel. A bit different Witbier with nice IPA-elements.

A fun, drinkable and somewhat challenging wit beer. Lots of subtle flavours happening on the tongue...clove, banana, pepper, spice, anise. and a beautifully balanced dry finish make this a memorable beer. Not something super special...but certainly a good memory.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a very large sized head of foamy fine to large sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a slightly hazy yellow white colored body and a thick foamy lacing. The weak aroma was malty banana and coriander. . The flavor contained notes of floral coriander hops and malt. An OK brew just nothing special.

Sampled on 6/17/2010. This wit pours a  slightly hazy medium orange gold color from a 750ml bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet, with some tartness and some spices. A medium bodied wit. The malts are fruity and sweet with a tart finish. Yeasty and bright. The hops are floral and spicy. Light and refreshing. Lively carbonation. Nice spicy finish. This is a nice beer for a warm summer evening. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter with some spiciness.
A really good beer. Yellow and light golden in color. Coriander very strong in it. Lots of citrus flavors. A really good beer. I like the mix between the hoppyness and the witbier notes.

From a 1.9 Pint bottle, Dark Golden in color,white head,fizzy,This taste exactly what i thought it would be a India Pale Whitbier beer hoppy,coriander,and creamy ,yet i believe there could be a better version with more hops.

The beer pours a hazy yellow color with a fluffy white head. The aroma is pretty basic with a mix of coriander, orange peel and lemons. The flavor is pithy oranges with coriander and pepper. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. The beer is very soft on the palate. Another good beer from Mikkeller.
Bottle. Aroma of hops, oats and grass. unclear yellow colour wit white head. Flavour of oats, wheat and discrete corianderseeds. Mild and hoppy at the same time. What a wit. Happy hoppy.

Beautiful hop spicy aroma not too overwhelming. Dirty hazy golden color. For a very hoppy wit not too bold on the palate.  Somewhat sharp hop bite on the tongue. Full bodied for a wit, not really but a nice refresher.

(750 ml bottle).  Pours hazy yellow-orange liquid with thick white head.  Yeast is evident and small carbonation bubbles.  Aroma is musty, sour orange, some spice.  Hop bitterness is surprising in the taste, almost peppery in the finish.  Celery?  Would have liked it a little sweeter; not as refreshing as a regular wit, but interesting.  Alcohol is evident as it warms the chest/back of the throat.  This is worth revisiting.

Interesting idea, but it just doesnt quite seem to work for me. The premise is fine, but the result IMHO doesnt really hold up. Poured with a great huge foamy frothy fluffy cream colored head and lots of lace. Color is a very hazy to slightly cloudy amber. Aroma is yeast hops malt spice citrus. Flavor is like that too but with the orange peel and prominant added spice that seems to clash a bit with the hops. Body is good and so is  carbonation. Finish is a fairly short odd bittersweet. Alcohol is muted. Its ok, but I dont think Id get another any time soon.

Pours pale amber, with a huge creamy head  that leaves plent of lacing. Smooth body with nice carbonation. Spices, citrus and some sweetness followed by bitterness from the hops.  A bit too much bitterness for me though.

Bottle; poured a dull amber/gold color wtih a big off white head.  Aroma of wheat, yeast, spice, and a solid amount of hopping (cascade).   Reminds me of a Belgian IPA, a style that has never eally clicked for me in terms of flavor.  I just dont find the elements, of yeast, wheat, spice, and hops to blend all that well together.  Still its probably an average beer overall for me.

Pour is hazed orangey amber with a thin sticky off white head...smell is hoppy (grapefruit) and perfumey with lots of grassy notes too...I guess I can get a bit of orange and coriander, but they sure seem subdued...the taste is like a medicinal/herbal IIPA...strongly citric and hoppy right up front...grapefruit...then a subtle sweetness attempts to back up the hoppy bitter flavor as an herbal and medicinal quality takes root...finish is chewy and cloying and herbal...an interesting and gross example of a style that should not exist?

1 pint 9.4 oz. Hazy golden orange with frothy white head that thins. Aroma of sweet citrus fruit (apple, orange), honey, other fruity esters with yeast, Starts lightly bitter and ends sweet dry, flavors of sour pear and other tart fruits, also some spices. Bitter throughout. Alive on the tongue

This beer pours a cloudy dull yellow with a thin white head and yeasties floating around (forgot to let them settle).  The aroma is flowers, perfume and light citrus lemon.  the palate is sticky sweet with a little bit of a sharp bite and a little dryness on the back end.  This was really a good beer.  Very unusual for a wit I think but very good nonetheless!  Cheers!

750ml Bottle (at 8%ABV):  Aroma of yeast, bubblegum, fruit, wheat, hops, slight orange, slight coriander, and light citrus.  Poured amber/yellow in color with a small, white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling to very sparkling.  Full of tiny, small, and medium-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of wheat, lemon, yeast, bubblegum, light hops, slight coriander, and resin.  Medium body.  Slick, then lightly dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Wheat, lemon, hops, and slight resin finish is dry.  8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

pours a clear orange with a large off-white head, and great lacing.

smell is of lemon, and wheat.

taste is of wheat, citrus, and some orange peel, ends tangy on the tongue yet dry.

Such disappointment--this was a beer I had sought out deliberately for its category-topping rating in the Witbier category. But--indeed as its makers claim--this represents the birth of a new category. Yes, the cloudiness, the esteryness [restrained, primarily coriander] are there, but theres a whole lot of IBU-straining bitter here too. Hoppy, hoppy, hoppy. Like wit for the West Coast IPA-heads, i guess...not my thing but props for originality ($14.99--pricey originality)

Shared by bhensonb. Pours cloudy light gold with a massive white head and a floral fruity aroma. This is truly not a typical witbier. Its a little darker with a more substantial malt flavor and a nutty finish. There is noticeable hop bitterness.

750. Pours hazy orange with a 4 finger clingly, foamy off-white head. Light citrus/spice aroma. Medium body with spritely carbonaton. Drinks like a Belgian ale rather thean wit. Seems to have cardamom. Nice beer.
Interesting. They claim to be the first IPW and it is a true mix of IPA and white bear. On tap at the Beer Temple.

750ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy, glowing, golden-orange color.  A small but lasting head of frothy, off-white foam is circled with a thick rim, and leaves sticky, pronounced, splotchy lacing on the glass.  The aroma is based in fresh, sweet dough and golden wheat, with notes of lemongrass, oily lemon peel, bitter coriander, and creamy citrus chiffon. Flavors are sparked with bright lemonpeel notes, hinting at pithy bitterness and soft, peppery grass, all over a malt base of golden wheat and clean cereal.  A surprisingly ultra-grassy hop-burp hit me a few minutes after the finish.  The palate sports a medium body that is relatively dry, with a lightly fizzy, persistent carbonation throughout. Solid brew, and better than expected.
From a bottle poured a hazy straw color with a good amount of head.  Spicy malty sweet flavor with a quick finish.

On tap at Beer Temple. Murky yellow body with nice white head. Nose of wheat and citrus. Quite a funny drink with white beer, sure, but also quite spicy. And hoppy. Nicely done and goes down very well.

On tap at Beer Temple. Hazy/unclear yellow orange colour, dense pillowy white head. Aroma of wheat, coriander, and really nice citrussy and spicy hops. Flavour is sweet, wheat, slightly malty, citrus, light grapefruit, light spicy, good firm but smooth hoppy bitter finish. Medium bodied, thick oily mouthfeel. Leaves you wanting for more.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2011 Bottle. Moderate aromas of grain and hay, heavy lemon for the hops, light earthy, peaty, musty note for the yeast, with hints of apple, oak, corriander and pepper. Head is large, fizzy, white with excellent lacing on the latest pour and is mostly diminishing. Color is hazy amber/tan. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then has a long moderately bitter finish. Palate is medium, oily with a lively to fizzy carbonation and finishes dry. This is a nice, bitey Witbier.

750ml bottle, drank in Jan 09. Poured golden, clear. Massive white head, great lacing. Aroma is hops, orange, lemon and yeast with a hint of spiciness. Flavor is pretty much the same, nice bitterness.
75cl, new Danish brew Anno 2008, from the brewery, complex brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, very good Belgian White, original brew!

Brown bottle, 750 ml, best before 23/10/11, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on January 30 2010; eye: golden, clear, no effervescence, voluminous white head made up of rather large bubbles and that turns into an island of melting ice cream, lots of lacing; nose: pine, light floral hops, light coriander, light orange, yeast; mouth: light coriander, light floral hops, pine, yeast, finale in pine with presence of spices, medium-light body, below-average carbonation, lightly bitter and acidic; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 750 ml, meilleure avant 23/10/11, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 30 janvier 2010; il : dorée, claire, pas deffervescence, mousse blanche abondante formée de bulles plutôt grosses et qui se transforme en un îlot de crème glacée fondante, beaucoup de dentelle; nez : pin, léger houblon floral, léger coriandre, léger orange, levure; bouche : léger coriandre, léger houblon floral, pin, levure, finale en pin avec présence dépices, corps moyen-léger, carbonatation sous la moyenne, légèrement amère et acide; en résumé : bien bon

One of the best beers ive ever had, i wih i gave this one the proper respect becasue in fairness to my rating, i was not sober at the time. But as drunk as i was, remembering this one was a light in the fog, absolutely delicious, great orange peel zest and coriander balance in the taste and just enough of a bight in the aftertaste that made this really enjoyable. another great one from mikkeller.
mamma mia quant è bona sta birraaaaaaaaaaaaaa!!!!! troppo equilibrata! è una blanche corposa freska luppolata profumata e troppo rinfreskante!!

Bottle. Pours straw yellow with a gigantic white head that literally laces the entire glass as you drink it. Smell is typical, orange, banana, coriander, yeast. Taste is hoppy with those notes. Definitely the best wit Ive ever tried.

Pours a translucent light yellow with some speckles of yeast. Has a towering white head that is just insane: about four fingers high in the tulip that has insane lacing and crazy retention. It settles down asymmetrically so that some of the head stays in a little island in the middle like a scoop of ice cream. Aroma is amarillo hops, mustiness, orange peel, potpourri, coriander, apple pie. Taste is lightly hoppy, a bit peppery, dry throughout. Light to medium bodied. Very saison like and thus awesome.

Refreshing yet a bit strong for a Wit. Cloudy and honey colored with a thick white head. Hoppy aroma, citrus, yeast and lemon drops. Medium bodied with a bitter finish. Hoppy bitter flavor. Bitterness lingers. Overall as advertised. Definitely not another Wit.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Pours amber/orange with a white head.  Aroma of cloves, orange peel, belgian barnyard funky yeast.  Taste is pretty much the same with something I cant put my finger on.  Thicker then most belgian wits.  Good stuff.
light scent of floral hops. lots of chalky white seamonkies floating about. appealing hop taste without the bitterness. suprisingly thick for this style. soft carbonation. awesome witbier!

75cl bottle from Total Wine (Tampa, FL). Pours a hazy dark golden color with a massive two finger white head that settles slowly and heavily laces the glass. Aroma is floral with notes of banana, citrus, clove, coriander, yeast, bread, some hints of honey and caramel. Flavor is sweet and floral with notes of honey, vanilla, yeast, bread, spice, caramel, coriander, orange peel, hints of mustiness. Medium body with a much thicker mouthfeel than most wits. Nice.

Pours a hazy gold with rich creamy white head.  Nose is outstanding, with pungent notes of citrus, wet hay and a hint of bubblegum.  Doughy with sugar pops and a surprising amount of hop bitterness.  Really unique... though it is slightly warm (abv) with a hint of astringency.  A slight barnyard funk/tartness lingers on finish... and I like that.  Overall... pretty good brew.

Bottle. Pours a deep golden with a big white head. Very fragrant, with notes of perfumey citrus and spices. sweet entry to the palate, lots of spicy fruit with a wheaty backbone, then a dry finish that is a little funky and surprisingly bitter. An unusual wit for sure, but really tasty and enjoyable.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: A clear yellow/golden colored beer, with a thick foamy white head. The aroma of hop bitter with fruits and some yeast. The taste of hop bitters. Its dry. There are fruits like citrus with hints of bananas. Spices like coriander in the back. The aftertaste is bitter and a little sweet.

Pours a hazy gold into a snifter. Bright white head quickly recedes to skim surface and hug rim. Bright saaz and orange aromas. Upfront slick orange peel and wheat turning hoppy in the lasting resin finish.

Bouteille de 750 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur dagrumes avec une pointe dépices. Apparence: La couleur est blonde légèrement voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes avec une pointes dépices et de miel. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement astringente. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de zestes de citron en arrière goût. (Rating #2764)
Another damn fine impressive beer from Mikkeller. It has aromas of honey and spice. Sits very well on the tongue and is remarkably smooth. Flavor is of honey, spice, and hops. Very enjoyable.
Bottle. Golden- orange colour with a white head. Aroma is hop, citrus, orange. Flavour is hop, citrus, orange, coriander, yeast, spices. Full bodied nice beer

Bottle.

Poured clear orange color with a medium frothy white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate yeasty citrus hop aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and lively carbonation. Medium citrus sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration with a small alcohol burn as it warmed.

My expectations where met.
750ml bottle at a tasting. Nose if fruity hops and somewhat spicy. Taste is hoppy, very fruity and spicy.

750mL bottle.  Poured healthy lighter golden with a thick, well-retained off-white head.  The aroma picked up bright earthy and grassy hoppage as well as lemon zest over sweeter light fruits and a touch of toasty banana.. grains of paradise and cloves accented.. I dug it.  The flavor opened with tart orange zest (grains of paradise and coriander this time), with pale and light bready malts settling onto the middle.. more tacky spices and lots of floral and citrusy bitterness on the finish.. OK stuff, but kind of sharp.  Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation on the palate.. tangy, bitter, and engaging.. too heavy for it to be refreshing.

750mL bottle. Pours a hazy, medium tarnished-golden color; thin off-white head with decent lacing. Sweet, juicy apricots in the aroma, with honey and Belgian sugar; a bit of bananas and creme brulee; complex sweetness, a touch syrupy. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: avg carbonation; again, lots of chewy Belgian sugar and juicy fruitiness; a syrupy sweet core without blatant sugar; nicely dense, solid mineral bitterness throughout; honestly, just a bit much; dense, ok drinkability. Lengthy finish: lots of mineral bitterness, nicely toasty and dry.

750ml bottle, yellow gold colr, with a rocky white head, leaving some belgian laces, yeasty fruity, green apple skin, pineapple, mango, citrus lemon peel nose, with a nice coriander spicy, honeyed wheaty, pale malt accent, with some mild floral hop saaz, cascade oarngeish, peachy aromas follow through on a medium-bodied palate, with a yeasty, fruity, pineapple, mango, wheaty, pale malt, oat cereal character with a good flowery hop, leafy, citrusy, zesty, lemony, faint peachy flavors, leading towards a warming, zesty, lemon peel, citrusy, lingering hop leafy bitterness finish.

750 ml bottle - pours hazy and glowing straw yellow with long lasting fluffy white head; orange, lemon, coriander, wheat and yeast; lovely nose; grainy, lemons and sweet flavors; soft texture with mildly sweet finish; coriander level is prefect

In short: A lot of floral hops in a big thick doughy yeasty wheaty brew of kind.  Originally very interesting.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed fresh a few weeks after receiving it through private importation
The look: Cloudy blonde body topped by a medium white head
In long: The nose is something that Id describe as pastry/bakery next to a bouquet of flowers.  I like a full malted body but this one is more like a big yeast dough.  Not unpleasant at all, just, you know, very thick.  The beer is incredibly yeasty but with very little fruity esters.  Taste is bready, doughy, floury, bakery, wheat.  A whole lot of floral hops and light fruity notes of apricots and citrus lighten up the experience.  This is a different beer.  It was very different from any other so-called imperial-witbier Ive had.  I really liked it although I must admit that most of my enjoyment came from its uniqueness.  A different beer and this time my closing line is Not Just Another Witty Comment.

Cloudy dark yellow with a fluffy white head.  Earthy hoppy aroma with notes of woody spice and bread.  Sweet pineapple and pear taste with some orange notes lingering in the background, hoppy bitterness, and pine notes to the finish.

Bottled. Hazy golden with a rich white foam. Yeasty and fruity aroma of pine-apples with a subtle spiciness. Medium-bodied with notes of mild spicy notes of coriander and white pepper with fruity undertones of dried apricots and pine-apples. Dryish yeasty finish of crackers, banana and dried apricots.

Pale yellow body under a bright white, sticky head with strong lacing. 
Aroma is faint, but enticing, banana, cloves, wheat, pepper. 
Flavor is cinnamon, banana, arugula, and peppercorns. 
Texture is dry, crisp, active, and lightly biting. 
Overall, a great hoppy take on the style, and a delicious example of a witbier.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 Bottle and served in my NB worthy glass: Hazy golden hue with a lasting frothy head which left outstanding lace upon the glassware. The aroma has notes of shocking piney and resiny hops, corriander, pepper and clove, wheat husk and pale biscuity malts, orange peel and grapefruit, and some medicinal aspirin vapours. The taste follows suit with in your face hop bitterness and acidity, perhaps just too much as the base witbier character really struggles to be make a mark. Finally some spices (other than hop spice tones) and wheaty and yeasty undertones. The mouth feel is lively and aggressive, which a slightly off-putting metallic and aspirin finish. Normally I would all over this beer as I like the "hoppy Belgian style" but then is just a tad too much, better than the cloy Great Divide before it but still not in the class of the better Wits on the market. (funking hopheads anyway)... give me a Hoegaarden, Abbaye des Rocs Blanche, Allagash White or Bells Winter White any day of the week!

Thanks to Dmac for this one. Pours out a cloudy golden color well carbonated, with a two finger white head. Aroma has some floral notes, wheat malts, slight hop and some spices going on in there too. Taste is clean and well balanced, easy drinking. Flavors of citrus, pepper, spice, wheat malt notes and a touch of hops. Usually everything in this style is rather meh, but this one was pretty decent.

Not the most impressive pour with a golden hazed body sitting underneath an average sized bubbly white head. Aroma is juicey with lots of hops followed by spices..pepper, corriander, notes of wheat, grass, lemon zest and orange citrus. Flavor has lots of orange juice, wheat and grass blending togeether. Medium bodied with average carbonation. After wahoo and exit 11 this one is really well done and just plain nice to see someone can pull of this style.

Heavily yeasty ale chocked with sediments floating in its dull murky golden robe. Concentrated wheat, coriander, orange juice meet soapy, perfumey, floral and zesty aromatic hops. This is a chewy wheat beer with a thick cerealic/wheaty palate. Its massive hop dose procures more aromas than bitterness, yet the bitterness is quite intense, bringing on a profound dry-out effect which quickly gather a cementy, stoney feel. Fat and oily palate is fortunately punctuated by fit effervescence which at least manage to impart some drinkability. Lots of alcohol  wave through the whole flavour development. I cant blame it for not being original, Ive never had its like, but I cant quite get a grip on such a detached fruity bitterness. A love or hate beer? I guess so.

Rated from memory.  750 ml bottle shared with a buddy.  Beautiful coriander and citrus nose.  Heavier body with full effervescence. Absolutely gorgeous hop bitterness that works very well with the flavours.  Loved it.

My Bottom Line:
Doughy yeast and citrusy, resinous hops coalesce in this fresh, creative and classy Imperial Witbier.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sheet of foam protects the cloudy whitish gold.
-The hop character is vibrant, yet it never overthrows the wheat beer character.
-This is very drinkable for its size.
-The resinous hop bitterness is levelled with the rest of the flavor profile.
-The bubbles are big, but remain comfortable throughout.
-The spicy, herbal, resinous, citrusy hop diversity is the perfect match for the Witbier it decorates.

Bottle.

Not Just Another Great Mikkeller...!  750ml bottle, caged and (synthetic) corked.  Deep golden color.  White creamy head.  Just the look and smell alone is enough for me to change my favorite style to Belgian White (Witbier) from Weizen Bock!  Aroma of wheat, malts, and lots of hops.  Oh I love the smell of Amarillo Hops.  Nice citrus with a slight hint of pine resin.  Slight orange zest.  Flavor is very bready.  Nice malt.  Creamy texture with a hit of toasted oats.  The beer is a bit stronger than I had expected.  An Imperial Belgian Wit??  I like it!  Finishes with a pine hop bitterness.  A distant fruit flavor as well.  Perhaps the coriander.    I would never imagine a Witbier to be paired with a Porterhouse steak.  This beer is so full bodied, it could.  Cheers!  Follow up: 1st Belch was of pineapple, 2nd belch was of mangoes.  A truly awesome beer.

Thanks to Savvy1982 for smuggling this back from Montana for me! Pours a hazy yellow/orange. The head is large with good retention and lacing. The aroma smells pretty typical of a wit, just stronger and with a little bit more complexity. Bananas, coriander, straw, citrus, Belgian yeast, bread, and (to me anyway) very distinct Styrian Golding in the aroma. The tastes is really quite nice. Its earthy, woodsy, sweet and bitter. Notes of mangoes, oranges, pineapple, coriander, pine, bananas, straw, and it has a nice long (for a wit anyway) bitter finish. Damn fine stuff!
Cloudy straw colored.  Mild citrus and banana aroma.  Very hoppy for a wheat, but not in a bad way.  Refreshing, nice bitter finish.

750->weizen:  pours a huge, lasting,  white head that exhibits excellent lacing atop a murky, cloudy, yellow body.  Aroma of herbs, citrus, and pineapple.  The body is light, texture sticky with average carbonation and a metallic finish.  The flavors duration is avorage, lightly sweet, acidic, and bitter, with a mouthfeel of minerals.

Bottled. Yellow coloured. Unclear. Dense whitish head. Spice, sweetness, fruits and orange in the aroma. Flavour is spiced (coriander), full of fruits and quite grapish. Quite refreshing. Medium to full bodied. Quite dry. Grapish and light spiced end.

Bottle. Pours a mildly hazy yellow/orange, with a frothy white head and lovely lacing. Nose is immediately hoppy, bright fresh citrus hops with oranges, wheat, spices underneath. Palate begins very hoppy, a touch of spruce/pine and then the citrus takes over. Hoppy citrus transistions seamlessly into the bright orange peel that I have come to expect from a witbier, then the mouthcoating wheat character takes over. Hops come back into center stage during the finish, though they are present through the entire flavor. Fascinating and unique stuff.

750ml bottle from Olbutikken.
Pours hazy orange with a firm white head.
Oranges, pineapple, citrus, spicy and bitter.

The mouthfeel is a lot like orange juice.
Bottle. Nice color! VERY yellow. Has a lot of things that a belgian white should have, but i would have like some more depth or even some funk.

1 ping 9.4 oz. bottle from Greens on Ponce De Leon. For number 600, I thought I would treat myself. Beer has a nice look to it. Fluffy head. Dark orange haze color. Looks pretty damn good. It looks really good. Head fades away quickly, but it still looks pretty good. Very hoppy aroma. I mean really hoppy; and for a witbier? What the hell? Slight sweet aroma, but the hops just dominate. Very pungent, but I wish they would have found a way to get the yeast and fruit/citrus aroma(s) in there. The beer is at first hoppy, and then some magic happens that only God knows about. The beer develops into a complex orange peel/citrus aroma. The hops at first arent overly annoying. Wow, a nice twist to a beer. The hops are playing less and less of a role as the beer warms up. That spice with orange citrus flavor is awesome. Very nuanced and very interesting. I was happy to see the hops take a backseat. Awesome wit. I agree this is not just another wit. It is pretty damn good. Fairly creamy. I love the hop twist on this thing very good.

Bottled. Cloudy golden color, medium frothy head. Aroma of orange peel, citrus, bit vanilla, yeast, hint of banana, quit hoppy. Bitter taste, fresh, orange and citrus. I was expecting an over the top imperial white, but it turned out to be very nice actually!

Bottle: Poured a hazy light golden yellow color ale with a quite large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of wheat malt and light spices is overshadowed by some Cascade, Saaz and Amarillo hops. Taste is also very much dominated by citrus notes originating from the Cascade hops and a dry finish from the Saaz hops. Body si full with limited filtration and great carbonation. Interesting experiment that made me realize that I like my Wit without too much hops.
Thanks to Nate for sharing!  Hazy bright orange pour.  Fluffy white head and spotty lace.  Lots of yeast floaters.  Spicy aroma.  Big hoppy citrus flavor, combined with hints of clove & grass
bottle, thick yellow color with milkshake foam, great dry citric spice aroma, flavor is very refined citrus, clove, bitter lasting finish, really good wit

Bottled. Aroma has orange peel, yeast, citric fruitiness, some spice. hazy, yellow-orange coloured with a white head. The taste is slightly sweet, more bitter, citric and balanced spicy. Reminded me a bit of the Hoegaarden Grand cru. Unless the high alcohol percentage for the style the beer is still quite refreshing. Before drinkin I expected this one to be a failed experiment, but I was all wrong. This beer is good!

Tons of orange peel in the aroma.  Pretty firm hop finish.  Its not bad, but its really not what I look for in a witbier.  This is heavy and yeasty like a Belgian golden or trippel.  I like a bit more lightness in my wits.

2008 Bottle; Sampled April 2009
A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a four-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head that is nice and long lasting and leaves a nice thick lace on the sides of my glass.  The beer is a bright gold color that shows hints of haze and a brighter gold color when held up to the light.  The aroma has an expressive, sweet orange zest note as well as a grassy, cracker like grain note.  The citrus aromatics are really the dominant note here; it is refreshing, but can seem a bit simplistic at times.

Sweet grain flavors mix with tart citrus notes (more than just orange, with some Meyer lemon notes) up front.  The finish has an astringency to it that is a bit like the pin in a citrus fruit, slightly tannic and bitter.  The finish also has a bit of spiciness to it; a earthy pepper not as well as a sort of green coriander flavor is noticeable.  Actually, speaking of green flavors, this beer actually has a green, sort of vegetable flavor to it.  The flavor is a cross between a bell pepper and a leafy herbal note; this last reminds me of a mix of basil and kefir lime leaf.  The flavor is spice and citrus dominated, but the grain does contribute a back drop of grassy wheat flavors, some sweet grain notes and a dry, cracker like grain note in the finish.  The body is a bit heavier than a standard strength Wit, with a touch of viscous heft and a noticeable body, but it is still quite quaffable and refreshing.

This is an enjoyable beer, especially if one is fond of Wits.  It is not overly complex and could certainly use some more fermentation complexity.

Big bottle, appearance is hazed gold with a large head in my Duvel.  Aroma of spice, typical Wit, fruity, and hops to differentiate.  The flavor is much the same with added bitterness.  Palate medium bodied and fairly quenching.  Overall, not exciting, but not bad.

Draft @ Lornd Nelson, Copenhagen. Pours a hazy orange color with a small white head. Has a fruity spicy wheat malty aroma with some hints of citrus and hops. Fruity wheat malty spicy citrus flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy citrus flavor with some hoppy bitter aftertaste.

750ml caged&corked bottle. Pours a cloudy brown/yellow gold with a very thick white head and many specks of dirt-like yeast chunks (hard to pour the bottle w/out stirring a little up). The aroma is funky and hoppy: subtle peppery phenols; yeasty, doughy bread; a touch of anise; aromatic bitter orange; and citrusy, earthy hops. The flavor starts fruity and spicy with lots of esters (pear, melon), lots of grassy, herbal, citrusy hops, and a nice, light, grainy, malt sweetness. There is something slightly medicinal about the combination. At mid-palate, the bitter citrus and grassiness strengthen along with a good bit of coriander and licorice-like esters. The finish is dry and hoppy with a touch of bready malt and lots of bitter fruit and aromatic spice. Overall, a very pleasant beer that kind of defies description. Belgian Strong Ale is certainly better than Witbier though...
bottle. Cloudy and poured with a big head, Bitterness develops over time. This is impressive even if like myself you are not a great fan of this style.

Tuulensuu, Tampere - thanks to the guy at the other table                                       
Hazy (dregs of bottle).  Aroma of hops and wheat.  Reasonably good hop profile, a little ginger in the palate.  Hops and a bit of grain.                               
Slightly sweet but not too much so.  Dont know what a whole glass would be like - probably would only add to the sense that its just, well, another wit.  Unusually, Phil did not share this.

750ml bottle. Spice aroma along with some grain. Deep golden body with big white head and some moderate lacing. Flavor is grainy and spice and some what chalky. Mild sweet grain aftertaste lingers to tell me this is just another wit but overpriced.

Poured a very cloudy bright gold with an eggshell white foam. Strong smells of coriander and pineapple, there is a dominant tropical character. I also get a little bit of ginger bread. A incredibly smooth silky body has low carbonation and in this case, that is a good thing. There is also some coriander, especially in the finish. I get some light pineapple and orange notes. Overall, this is a nicely made brew that is much smoother than I would have expected, given the alcohol level.

My Mikkeller of choice today is a Belgian Ale brewed with Spices which has now been clarified as a Witbier, aka Belgian White. It is not at all uncommon for Belgian and Belgian-style ales to have natural flavors of spice, wood, and such due wholly to the natural yeast strains and brewing processes. It also isnt unusual for those mischievous Belgians and their inspired cohorts to add a little extra punch of flavor, complexity, and uniqueness to their beer with the addition of spices, fruit, and so on. But that is a whole other barrel of brew for another discussion on a different day.


She poured a hazy golden-orange with a huge head gracefully adorning her beautiful colors. Appearing like a heavenly cloud descended, she fades slowly into soft tufts while sprinkles of lace adorn the sides of my glass. Wafting gently my way, her heady aroma of tart lemon and grapefruit, spices, clove, coriander, nutmeg and slightly funked sourdough and yeast seduces and woos. Divinely sublime, our lips meet in an effervescent kiss wet with yeast and sourdough speckled with spices. The spices act as a soothsayer for the tart character of my Mikkeller, mellowing some of the initial tartness and sour funk. Surprisingly, her finish has a sweet touch of sweet grass and dry hops. As my Mikkeller warms, more peppery spice and coriander adds zest while my palate slowly dries, leaving me thirsting for each subsequent tart quaff. There are a lot of things going on within this beer, yet she is amazingly quaffable with an amazing refreshing character. All good things must come to an end though, and as we bid each other farewell, I am left with one final embrace of tart citrus, sourdough, pepper spice and coriander so nice, marked by a seductive sweet nip.


Most impressive is my first foray into the brewery Mikkeller. I havent had any of their other offerings so I cant say if this is one of their best or their average fair, but I certainly wouldnt say mediocre. I think I enjoyed most the exquisitely balanced conflict of tart yet sweet, sour yet spiced. I definitely look forward to seeing what else Mikkeller has to offer.

Bottle. Great Beer. Pours a hazy yellow gold. Citrusy, wit spiced with nice Mikkeller hop presence. Taste has coriander, citrus zest, wheat with nice hop presence. Extremly drinkable. Houblon Chouffe with a wit rather than a tripel. Really liked this

750ml caged and rubber-corked bottle.  Served in a tulip.  A hazy golden pour with lots of noticable carbonation dancing up the glass.  A two-finger thick head of creamy beige foam stuck firm for a while, before settling into a lasting cap.  Excellent lacing.  The aroma included fresh orange zest, mild coriander, bread, light honey, and some lightly spicy yeast.  Also some added hoppy citrus.  Surprisingly, the flavor was somewhat dry.  Orange peel, lemon zest, wheat, spicy yeast, and a note of dry alcohol warmth that lingered.  Also a nice, crisp hoppy bite.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and had a decent amount of carbonation.  An interesting take on the style, but not the most drinkable.  Too much alcohol warmth in the finish.  I prefer wits to be a bit more crisp and refreshing.

Bottled in 2008.  Pours a very hazy, honey color with a moderately full, white, fluffy head which is mostly diminishing and leaves minimal lace.  Nose is nice with IPA notes as well as Wit notes; lots of coriander, wheat, grassy hops, orange and grapefruit peel, light clove, faint pine, and some light pepper.  Flavor is nothing like the nose suggested, lots of hops but not a lot of wit notes.  Tart orange peel and grapefruit notes to start, followed by light clove and coriander; the moderately high bitterness from the hops then engulfs all other flavors.  Notes of dry grass, light pine, and some peppery hops.  Palate is fair with a nearly medium body, a dry and watery texture, and a lively carbonation.  Finishes nearly all bitter with dry grass, light pepper, and faint grapefruit peel.  The aroma is a great balance of nice wit notes and hops, but the flavor is dominated by the bitterness and the hop flavors.  Very drinkable for the ABV and not overly sugary.  Excellent experiment but not one of favorite wits.
